body:
I found a weird case, and I'd like to confirm that what I'm doing is correct:

In the original `%` formatting version of the code, there's the following line in [pytables.py#532](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/core/computation/pytables.py#L532):
```python
where = ' & ' .join(["(%s)" % w for w in where])  # noqa
```

I originally switched this to `.format` via:
```python
where = ' & '.join(map('({})'.format, where))  # noqa
```
However, this didn't work and ended up failing a test in [test_pytables.py](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/tests/io/test_pytables.py#L2584-L2667).  Specifically, it failed because the test is passing nested tuples, such as `((("minor_axis==['A', 'B']"),),)`.  It looks like the `%` formatting code was using the fact that `%` formatting takes the first nested element of such a tuple, whereas `.format` formats the tuple as a whole.  My workaround was to use the `pandas.core.common.flatten` function as such:
```python
where = ' & '.join(map('({})'.format, com.flatten(where)))  # noqa
```

This passes the test that previously failed, but I'm not positive that it's the correct thing to do in all cases.  Can someone confirm that this is right, or suggest an appropriate alternative?
